We designed a mobile trolley system to facilitate the safe handling and transport of aircraft exhaust stack pipes. The project involved performing structural analysis and ergonomic assessments using CATIA V5 to ensure that the trolley could safely support the required loads while remaining stable and easy to maneuver. We also incorporated manufacturing constraints into the design process and proposed a cost-effective fabrication plan to ensure practical implementation.
Fabrication of Particle Image Velocimetry Setup at Low Reynolds Number

In this project, we designed and fabricated a Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) setup to study low Reynolds number flow over a flat plate (chord length 76.33 mm) in the range of Re = 2,000–10,000. The system utilized a Class IIIB laser for particle illumination, a Chronos 2.1 high-speed camera, and a smartphone camera for PIV and flow visualization. Velocity fields were obtained through cross-correlation of sequential images using PIVlab (MATLAB). The experimental data were analyzed to identify key flow features such as laminar separation bubbles, reattachment points, turbulent mixing, and trailing-edge vortex shedding. Results were further validated through CFD simulations conducted under similar conditions, and potential sources of experimental and processing errors were systematically evaluated.

In this project, we enhanced an existing MATLAB code for two-dimensional heat conduction based on the finite element method by adding functionality to incorporate internal heat sources. We also implemented routines to compute both the temperature distribution and the corresponding heat flux throughout the domain. These modifications improved numerical stability and introduced enhanced visualization outputs, making the tool more comprehensive and versatile for advanced thermal analysis applications.

We constructed a quadcopter using an Arduino Uno microcontroller and off-the-shelf components for demonstration at MechTRIX-X. We implemented PID control algorithms for roll and pitch stabilization and systematically tuned the control parameters to achieve a stable hover. The quadcopter was successfully demonstrated at MechTRIX-X, showcasing the integration of embedded programming, control theory, and mechanical design principles.

We designed and built an experimental setup using a load cell, LabVIEW, and NI DAQmx to acquire lift and drag data for a NACA 0012 airfoil. We integrated the control and data acquisition hardware to capture force measurements synchronized with flow conditions. The experimental results were validated through CFD simulations in Ansys, where we compared lift and drag coefficients across a range of angles of attack and identified potential sources of experimental error.
Bijuli – Powerline Inspection Fixed Wing Battery Powered UAV

In this project, we designed a fixed-wing, battery-powered UAV for power line inspection in Nepal. The project involved preliminary aerodynamic sizing, stability and control analysis, structural considerations, and detailed mission planning. We developed Python scripts to evaluate aerodynamic performance across various flight envelopes, enabling systematic assessment of efficiency and operational feasibility. The work culminated in a comprehensive poster presentation that highlighted the UAV’s technical capabilities and its potential impact on improving the safety, efficiency, and reliability of power line maintenance in remote regions.

This project focused on the aerodynamic design and numerical analysis of a single-stage subsonic axial flow compressor for a target mass flow rate of 8.2 kg/s and a design pressure ratio of 1.2. The study combined analytical mean-line theory, blade geometry development, structured meshing, and steady/transient CFD simulations to evaluate performance and flow physics. The objective was to design a low-aspect-ratio compressor stage without inlet guide vanes and validate its aerodynamic performance through high-fidelity numerical modeling.

## Design Methodology The design process began with preliminary mean-line analysis. A Python-based solver was developed to iteratively compute velocity triangles at the midspan by fixing the flow coefficient and loading coefficient. Free vortex radial equilibrium theory was applied to account for spanwise variations in whirl velocity. Using the specified mass flow rate, hub-to-tip ratio, and an assumed aspect ratio of 1.5, key aerodynamic parameters such as blade angles, axial velocity, degree of reaction, and rotor speed were calculated. The resulting rotor speed was approximately 11464 rpm with a tip radius of 0.2 m. Blade geometry was developed by constructing circular camber lines corresponding to the calculated flow angles at the hub, mean, and tip sections. A NACA 65-series airfoil (NACA 651212) was selected and superimposed on these camber lines to achieve an appropriate thickness distribution. The sections were stacked and smoothly blended in CATIA to generate the final three-dimensional blade geometry. --- ## Numerical Setup Structured multi-block hexahedral meshes were generated in ANSYS TurboGrid using O–H topology to ensure adequate boundary-layer resolution. The final mesh consisted of approximately 496,000 nodes with near-wall y+ values around 20. A mesh independence study was conducted to confirm solution stability. CFD simulations were performed in ANSYS CFX using the SST k–ω turbulence model. Both steady RANS simulations with a mixing plane interface and transient URANS simulations using a time transformation model were carried out to capture rotor–stator interaction effects. --- ## Results Steady-state simulations predicted a total pressure ratio of approximately 1.12 and an isentropic efficiency near 78 percent. Transient simulations revealed periodic pressure oscillations, with the pressure ratio varying between 1.13 and 1.17 due to blade row interaction. Although slightly below the target pressure ratio of 1.2, the results were achieved without geometric optimization, sweep, lean, or tip clearance modeling, demonstrating strong baseline aerodynamic performance. --- ## Flow Physics Observations Flow visualization revealed the presence of secondary flows and passage vortices, particularly near endwall regions. The rotor increased the absolute velocity of the flow and imparted kinetic energy, while the stator diffused the flow and converted kinetic energy into static pressure. Spanwise analysis indicated that meridional velocity decreased toward the tip, highlighting deviations from the constant axial velocity assumption used in preliminary design. These findings emphasized the inherently three-dimensional and unsteady nature of axial compressor flow. --- ## Technical Contributions This project demonstrates proficiency in turbomachinery aerodynamic design, velocity triangle analysis, free vortex modeling, CAD-based blade generation, structured meshing, RANS and URANS simulation, mesh independence verification, and performance evaluation under realistic engineering constraints.
Visiting Research Collaborators at Montana State University

I traveled to Montana State University to meet with our collaborators working on the near-field dynamics of vortex–surface interactions. During the visit, I learned about the flow visualization techniques they employ and observed their PIV setup to support the development of a similar system at UNH. The experience provided a valuable opportunity to learn from experts in the field and strengthen our collaborative research efforts.
Oral Presentation at American Physical Society: Division of Fluid Dynamics

I attended and presented my research progress and findings on vortex–surface interactions at the largest Fluid Mechanics Conference held in Houston, Texas. The conference provided an excellent opportunity to engage with leading experts in the field, receive valuable feedback, and discuss emerging developments and new results in fluid mechanics research.
Presenting at the Rocky mountain fluid symposium

I attended and presented my research progress and findings on vortex–surface interactions at the Fluid Mechanics Conference in Boulder, Colorado. The event provided a valuable platform to engage with experts in the field, exchange ideas, and discuss emerging results and advancements in fluid mechanics research.

I am currently working on an AFOSR-funded project on vortex–surface interaction, where I study the free-surface signature of a three-dimensional counter-rotating vortex pair and relate it to the subsurface dynamics, with applications in submarine stealth.
